report_title: Chicken Egg Production in the US
executive_summary: Over the past five years, chicken egg producers have had to contend with severe revenue volatility. While per capita egg consumption has remained stable, a severe drought across most of the United States pushed the price of feed upward. This, combined with lingering challenges from supply chain bottlenecks and highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), have pushed the price of eggs upward. Widespread inflation in 2022 also contributed to surging egg prices, and while the industry benefited from an upswing in revenue that year, price spikes set the stage for plummeting prices in 2023. As a result, industry-wide revenue has dropped at a CAGR of 2.4% to $11.3 billion over the five years to 2023, when revenue will drop an estimated 14.5%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While none have been as devastating as the 2015 outbreak, sporadic detections of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) have damaged US chicken flocks. The US Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) has been integral to catching detections early and containing the virus. Losses to flock sizes have dampened production volumes and contributed to rising egg prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Major price fluctuations have brought down revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The price of eggs has been highly volatile over the past five years, swinging upward in 2018, 2021 and 2022. Because of the combination of supply chain issues, post-pandemic inflation and lingering HPAI challenges, the price of eggs skyrocketed 70.7% in 2022. The price of eggs is expected to plummet in 2023 as grocery store prices begin to stabilize and the industry's challenges fade, bringing down revenue below pre-period levels.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profit expands as egg prices outpace feed costs
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Feed costs surged in 2021 and 2022 as a severe drought across most of the United States limited key crop yields, such as corn and soybeans. While feed costs have risen, egg prices have outpaced feed cost and allowed for more breathing room in the industry's cost structure. Despite heavy volatility, egg production companies have been able to expand their profit over the past five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Egg production shifts toward large facilities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Large companies have benefited from economies of scale by using intensive cage farming. Major operations with heightened profit will continue to invest in automation technology, dampening wage expenses. Medium-size egg production facilities that don't get bought by larger entities will invest in expanding their operations to spread fixed costs out over larger production capacities.

The price of eggs will continue to drop in 2023 and 2024 before returning to slow growth through the end of 2028. The stabilization of prices will help preserve demand from price-sensitive consumers, but the price of eggs won't return to 2022 and 2023 highs. Because egg prices will remain lower over the next five years, revenue will remain dampened after dropping off in 2023 and 2024.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: New regulations will restrict intensive cage production
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Many states, such as California and Minnesota, have introduced legislation governing the use of battery cages in egg production facilities. Intensive cage farming is seen by many as inhumane, and many animal rights activist groups will continue to lobby legislators for more restrictions on the use of battery cages. This will drive heightened organic and free-range egg production.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Feed costs drop and lift profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Profit will expand over the next five years as the price of feed steadily declines at a faster pace than egg prices. Severe weather events are unpredictable, though, and have the potential to vastly cut crop yields and drive up feed prices.

industry_definition: The Chicken Egg Production industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in raising chickens for egg production. These establishments may hatch their own chicks or raise chicks hatched elsewhere. The industry also includes establishments that produce eggs from other types of birds, such as ducks or quail.

positive_impact_factors: Demand from supermarkets and grocery stores
Demand from egg and poultry wholesaling

opportunities: Demand from supermarkets and grocery stores

key_trends: Organic egg production addresses health and ethical concerns

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Consumers in the Southeast create demand
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Because the Southeast holds over one-quarter of the nation's population, there is a high level of demand for eggs in consumer markets.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The Southeast has an extensive food processing industry
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The region also has an extensive network of food processing industries that rely on the Southeast's accessible workforce.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry faces increasing regulations around animal welfare, such as requirements for cage-free housing and humane treatment of chickens.
Egg producers must comply with food safety regulations from agencies like the FDA to ensure safe handling and processing of eggs.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Federal, state and local laws regulate various aspects of the industry, including the handling, storage and transportation of eggs. These regulations can be complex, time-consuming and costly to navigate for new entrants.
It's very expensive to acquire land, build infrastructure, purchase equipment and acquire birds to join the industry at a high production capacity.
The egg production industry is highly competitive and products are relatively homogenous. Still, entrants prioritizing quality, animal welfare or sustainability practices can gain an edge.
Egg production is a capital-intensive industry, and it's expensive to maintain and upgrade equipment, buildings and infrastructure.

factors_decreased_barrier: Easy access to further appropriate land for development

basis_points.basis_title: Use of specialist equipment or facilities
basis_points.basis_description: Access to the most recent technology relating to breeding, feed mixes and climate control can help increase output and operational efficiencies.
Production methods (e.g. free-range versus intensive cage) can affect profitability and consumer preferences.

concentration_points.concentration_title: What impacts the industry's market share concentration?
concentration_points.concentration_description: Barriers to entry are low. Because new entrants can determine the size of their egg operations, barriers to entry are low.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Economies of scale are elevating large companies
concentration_points.concentration_description: Intensive cage chicken farming has become the standard for the industry's largest companies.
Expanding profit is giving larger corporations the ability to acquire smaller competitors.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rising egg prices have lifted profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit accounts for an estimated 13.6% of revenue in 2023.
Wages account for an estimated 7.7% of revenue in 2023.
Purchases make up an estimated 44.1% of revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The chicken egg production industry has moderate capital intensity.
Large producers are increasingly investing in automation.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Prices fluctuate with supply and demand
volatility_points.volatility_description: Egg prices are volatile and fluctuate based on supply and demand conditions.
Eggs are a highly perishable product.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Large egg producers are increasingly adopting automation technologies.
Advances in breeding techniques and animal nutrition have increased productivity.

FAQs.question: What are the key financial metrics for the chicken egg production industry?
FAQs.answer: Some key financial metrics provided include profit margin, average wage, largest cost as a percentage of revenue.

FAQs.question: What trends have impacted industry costs in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Three key trends impacting costs are: 1) Rising egg prices have lifted profit, especially for large companies. 2) Automation has dampened wage costs as the industry implements machinery.

FAQs.question: What are some of the ratios and values shown for the balance sheet?
FAQs.answer: The data provides values for cash and equivalents, receivables, inventories, investments, property/plant/equipment and net worth.

FAQs.question: What liquidity and coverage ratios are included?
FAQs.answer: Liquidity ratios included are current ratio, quick ratio and receivables turnover.

FAQs.question: What key statistics and ratios are provided for recent years and projections?
FAQs.answer: Key statistics include revenue, IVA, number of establishments/enterprises, employment and imports.
